sourceDesc.bibl: Mackay, Jessie. The Voice of the River. The Spirit of the Rangatira and Other Ballads (Melbourne: Robertson, 1889), pp. 75-76.

projectDesc.p: Transcribed and encoded as part of "Settler Literature and Environmental Change in Australia and New Zealand," Marsden Fund Standard Grant 19-MAU-022 (Te Apārangi Royal Society of New Zealand).

lg.l: I hear thee to-night, О river! River. It is unclear if the poem invokes a particular river, but Mackay was born in the vicinity of the Rakaia river, in the Canterbury region of the South Island.
Methinks I hear thee to-night,
Afar in the midnight moaning
To pale starlight.
I hear thee, O desolate river!
And the sad winds stir
As if when the world was sleeping
They mourned for her.
And thou for the lives, O river!
That passed away on thy tide, Passed away on thy tide. Drowning was referred to in colonial New Zealand as “the New Zealand death.”
Thy conscience moans at midnight
For those who died.
I hear thee, O lonely river!
Dash on the rocks thy spray;—
Methinks I hear thee at midnight
Though far away.
Now art thou loud, O river!
And thy voice more wild and high;
Thy welcome it is to the morning
That now is nigh.
Like the sons of earth, thou river!
Thy tears flow in the night;
Like them thy smiles awaken
In morning light.
